type.description:

For example: Process Activity: Launch.

The unique identifier of the related OCSF event type.

For example: 100701.

The type of the related OCSF event, as defined by type_uid.

For example: Process Activity: Launch.

kill_chain.description: The Cyber Kill Chain® provides a detailed description of each phase and its associated activities within the broader context of a cyber attack.

job.description: The Job object provides information about a scheduled job or task, including its name, command line, and state. It encompasses attributes that describe the properties and status of the scheduled job.

uid.description: The Common Weakness Enumeration unique number assigned to a specific weakness. A CWE Identifier begins "CWE" followed by a sequence of digits that acts as a unique identifier. For example: CWE-123.
uid.caption: CWE ID

caption.description: The caption assigned to the Common Weakness Enumeration unique identifier.
caption.caption: Caption

src_url.description: URL pointing to the CWE Specification. For more information see CWE.
src_url.caption: Source URL

cwe.name: cwe
cwe.description: The CWE object represents a weakness in a software system that can be exploited by a threat actor to perform an attack. The CWE object is based on the Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) catalog.
cwe.caption: CWE

category.description: The name of the data classification category that data matched into, e.g. Financial, Personal, Governmental, etc.
category.caption: Category

pattern_match.description: A text, binary, file name, or datastore that matched against a detection rule.
pattern_match.caption: Pattern Match

3.description: Any financially-related sensitive information or Cardholder Data (CHD). E.g., banking account numbers, credit card numbers, International Banking Account Numbers (IBAN), SWIFT codes, etc.
3.caption: Financial

6.description: Any sensitive security-related data such as passwords, passkeys, IP addresses, API keys, credentials and similar secrets. E.g., AWS Access Secret Key, SaaS API Keys, user passwords, database credentials, etc.
6.caption: Security

99.description: Any other type of data classification or a multi-variate classification made up of several other classification categories.
99.caption: Other

0.description: The type is not mapped. See the data_type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
0.caption: Unknown

1.description: Any Personally Identifiable Information (PII), Electronic Personal Health Information (ePHI), or similarly personal information. E.g., full name, home address, date of birth, etc.
1.caption: Personal

2.description: Any sensitive government identification number related to a person or other classified material. E.g., Passport numbers, driver license numbers, business identification, taxation identifiers, etc.
2.caption: Governmental

4.description: Any business-specific sensitive data such as intellectual property, trademarks, copyrights, human resource data, Board of Directors meeting minutes, and similar.
4.caption: Business

5.description: Any mission-specific sensitive data for military, law enforcement, or other government agencies such as specifically classified data, weapon systems information, or other planning data.
5.caption: Military and Law Enforcement

category_id.description: The normalized identifier of the data classification category.
category_id.caption: Category ID

confidentiality.description: The file content confidentiality, normalized to the confidentiality_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.
confidentiality.caption: Confidentiality

99.description: The confidentiality is not mapped. See the confidentiality attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
99.caption: Other

confidentiality_id.description: The normalized identifier of the file content confidentiality indicator.
confidentiality_id.caption: Confidentiality ID

data_lifecycle_state.description: The name of the stage or state that the data was in. E.g., Data-at-Rest, Data-in-Transit, etc.
data_lifecycle_state.caption: Data Lifecycle State

3.description: The data was being processed, accessed, or read by a system, making it active in memory or CPU. E.g., sensitive data in a Business Intelligence tool, ePHI being processed in an EHR application or a user viewing data stored in a spreadsheet or PDF.
3.caption: Data in-Use

0.description: The type is not mapped. See the data_lifecycle_state attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
0.caption: Unknown

1.description: The data was stored on physical or logcial media and was not actively moving through the network nor was being processed. E.g., data stored in a database, PDF files in a file share, or EHR records in object storage.
1.caption: Data at-Rest

2.description: The data was actively moving through the network or from one physical or logical location to another. E.g., emails being send, data replication or Change Data Capture (CDC) streams, or sensitive data processed on an API.
2.caption: Data in-Transit

data_lifecycle_state_id.description: The stage or state that the data was in when it was assessed or scanned by a data security tool.
data_lifecycle_state_id.caption: Data Lifecycle State ID

detection_pattern.description: Specific pattern, algorithm, fingerpint, or model used for detection.
detection_pattern.caption: Detection Pattern

detection_system.description: The name of the type of data security tool or system that the finding, detection, or alert originated from. E.g., Endpoint, Secure Email Gateway, etc.
detection_system.caption: Detection System

3.description: A Mobile Device Management (MDM) or Enterprise Mobility Management (EMM) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies on mobile devices (e.g., cellphones, tablets, End User Devices [EUDs]).
3.caption: Mobile Device Management

6.description: A Secure Email Gateway (SEG) is any tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies within email systems. E.g., Microsoft Defender for Office, Google Workspaces.
6.caption: Secure Email Gateway

99.description: Any other type of detection system or a multi-variate system made up of several other systems.
99.caption: Other

0.description: The type is not mapped. See the detection_system attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
0.caption: Unknown

1.description: A dedicated agent or sensor installed on a device, either a dedicated data security tool or an Endpoint Detection & Response (EDR) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies. E.g., Forcepoint DLP, Symantec DLP, Microsoft Defender for Endpoint (MDE).
1.caption: Endpoint

2.description: A Data Loss Prevention (DLP) gateway that is positioned in-line of an information store such as a network share, a database, or otherwise that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies.
2.caption: DLP Gateway

10.description: A built in Data Loss Prevention (DLP) or other data security capability within a tool or platform such as an Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) or Customer Relations Management (CRM) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies.
10.caption: Application-Level DLP

4.description: A tool that actively identifies and classifies sensitive data in digitial media and information stores in accordance with a policy or automated functionality. E.g, Amazon Macie, Microsoft Purview.
4.caption: Data Discovery & Classification

5.description: A Secure Web Gateway (SWG) is any tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies at a network-edge such as within a proxy or firewall service.
5.caption: Secure Web Gateway

7.description: A Digital Rights Management (DRM) or a dedicated Information Rights Management (IRM) are tools which can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies on digitial media via policy or user access rights.
7.caption: Digital Rights Management

8.description: A Cloud Access Security Broker (CASB) that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies in-line to cloud systems such as the public cloud or Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) tool. E.g., Forcepoint CASB, SkyHigh Security.
8.caption: Cloud Access Security Broker

9.description: A Database Activity Monitoring (DAM) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies as part of a dedicated database or warehouse monitoring solution.
9.caption: Database Activity Monitoring

11.description: Any Developer Security tool such as an Infrastrucre-as-Securty (IAC) scanner, Secrets Detection, or Secure Software Development Lifecycle (SSDLC) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies. E.g., TruffleHog, GitGuardian, Git-Secrets.
11.caption: Developer Security

12.description: A Data Security Posture Management (DSPM) tool is a continuous monitoring and data discovery solution that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies for local and cloud environments. E.g., Cyera, Sentra, IBM Polar Security.
12.caption: Data Security Posture Management

detection_system_id.description: The type of data security tool or system that the finding, detection, or alert originated from.
detection_system_id.caption: Detection System ID

policy.description: Details about the policy that triggered the finding.
policy.caption: Policy

data_security.caption: Data Security

The Policy object describes the policies that are applicable.

Policy attributes provide traceability to the operational state of the security product at the time that the event was captured, facilitating forensics, troubleshooting, and policy tuning/adjustments.

cis_benchmark.description: The CIS Benchmark object describes best practices for securely configuring IT systems, software, networks, and cloud infrastructure as defined by the Center for Internet Security. See also Getting to Know the CIS Benchmarks.

name.description: The CIS benchmark name.

desc.description: The CIS benchmark description.

cis_benchmark_result.name: cis_benchmark_result
cis_benchmark_result.description: The CIS Benchmark Result object contains information as defined by the Center for Internet Security (CIS) benchmark result. CIS Benchmarks are a collection of best practices for securely configuring IT systems, software, networks, and cloud infrastructure.
cis_benchmark_result.caption: CIS Benchmark Result

interface_name.description: The name of the network interface (e.g. eth2).

namespace_pid.description: If running under a process namespace (such as in a container), the process identifier within that process namespace.

zone.description: The network zone or LAN segment.

network_endpoint.description: The Network Endpoint object describes characteristics of a network endpoint. These can be a source or destination of a network connection.

algorithm.description: The concatenation of key exchange, encryption, authentication and compression algorithms (separated by ';'). NOTE: This is not the underlying algorithm for the hash implementation.

fingerprint.description: The hash of the key exchange, encryption, authentication and compression algorithms.

hassh.description: The HASSH object contains SSH network fingerprinting values for specific client/server implementations. It provides a standardized way of identifying and categorizing SSH connections based on their unique characteristics and behavior.
hassh.caption: HASSH

name.description: The name of the resource.
name.caption: Name

owner.description: The identity of the service or user account that owns the resource.
owner.caption: Owner

type.description: The resource type as defined by the event source.

version.description: The version of the resource. For example 1.2.3.

group.description: The name of the related resource group.

namespace.description: The namespace is useful when similar entities exist that you need to keep separate.

agent_list.description: A list of agent objects associated with a device, endpoint, or resource.
agent_list.caption: Agent List

cloud_partition.description: The canonical cloud partition name to which the region is assigned (e.g. AWS Partitions: aws, aws-cn, aws-us-gov).
cloud_partition.caption: Cloud Partition

criticality.description: The criticality of the resource as defined by the event source.
criticality.caption: Criticality

data_classification.description: The Data Classification object includes information about data classification levels and data category types.
data_classification.caption: Data Classification

region.description: The cloud region of the resource.
region.caption: Region

resource_details.name: resource_details
resource_details.description: The Resource Details object describes details about resources that were affected by the activity/event.
resource_details.caption: Resource Details

code.description: The Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) status code returned from the web server to the client. For example, 200.
code.caption: Response Code

message.description: The description of the event/finding, as defined by the source.
message.caption: Message

status.description: The response status. For example: A successful HTTP status of 'OK' which corresponds to a code of 200.
status.caption: Status

length.description: The HTTP response length, in number of bytes.
length.caption: Response Length

content_type.description: The request header that identifies the original media type of the resource (prior to any content encoding applied for sending).
content_type.caption: HTTP Content Type

http_headers.description: Additional HTTP headers of an HTTP request or response.
http_headers.caption: HTTP Headers

latency.description: The HTTP response latency measured in milliseconds.
latency.caption: Latency

http_response.name: http_response
http_response.description: The HTTP Response object contains detailed information about the response sent from a web server to the requester. It encompasses attributes and metadata that describe the response status, headers, body content, and other relevant information.
http_response.caption: HTTP Response

control.description: A Control is prescriptive, prioritized, and simplified set of best practices that one can use to strengthen their cybersecurity posture. e.g. AWS SecurityHub Controls, CIS Controls.
control.caption: Security Control

status.description: The resultant status of the compliance check normalized to the caption of the status_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.
status.caption: Status

requirements.description: A list of requirements associated to a specific control in an industry or regulatory framework. e.g. NIST.800-53.r5 AU-10
requirements.caption: Compliance Requirements

standards.description: Security standards are a set of criteria organizations can follow to protect sensitive and confidential information. e.g. NIST SP 800-53, CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark v1.4.0, ISO/IEC 27001

An unordered collection of zero or more name/value pairs where each pair represents a file or folder extended attribute.

For example: Windows alternate data stream attributes (ADS stream name, ADS size, etc.), user-defined or application-defined attributes, ACL, owner, primary group, etc. Examples from DCS:

  • ads_name
  • ads_size
  • dacl
  • owner

cis_control.name: cis_control
cis_control.description: The CIS Control (aka Critical Security Control) object describes a prioritized set of actions to protect your organization and data from cyber-attack vectors. The CIS Controls are defined by the Center for Internet Security.
cis_control.caption: CIS Control

3.description: The intruders will use various tactics, such as phishing, infected USB drives, etc.
3.caption: Delivery

6.description: Malware opens a command channel to enable the intruders to remotely manipulate the victim's system.
6.caption: Command & Control

99.description: The kill chain phase is not mapped. See the phase attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
99.caption: Other

0.description: The kill chain phase is unknown.
0.caption: Unknown

1.description: The attackers pick a target and perform a detailed analysis, start collecting information (email addresses, conferences information, etc.) and evaluate the victim’s vulnerabilities to determine how to exploit them.
1.caption: Reconnaissance

2.description: The attackers develop a malware weapon and aim to exploit the discovered vulnerabilities.
2.caption: Weaponization

4.description: The intruders start leveraging vulnerabilities to executed code on the victim’s system.
4.caption: Exploitation

5.description: The intruders install malware on the victim’s system.
5.caption: Installation

7.description: With hands-on keyboard access, intruders accomplish the mission’s goal.
7.caption: Actions on Objectives

phase_id.description: The cyber kill chain phase identifier.

kill_chain_phase.name: kill_chain_phase
kill_chain_phase.description: The Kill Chain Phase object represents a single phase of a cyber attack, including the initial reconnaissance and planning stages up to the final objective of the attacker. It provides a detailed description of each phase and its associated activities within the broader context of a cyber attack. See Cyber Kill Chain®.
kill_chain_phase.caption: Kill Chain Phase

cpu_type.description: The processor type. For example: x86 Family 6 Model 37 Stepping 5.
cpu_type.caption: Processor Type

desktop_display.description: The desktop display affiliated with the event
desktop_display.caption: Desktop Display

ram_size.description: The total amount of installed RAM, in Megabytes. For example: 2048.
ram_size.caption: RAM Size

device_hw_info.name: device_hw_info
device_hw_info.description: The Device Hardware Information object contains details and specifications of the physical components that make up a device. This information provides an overview of the hardware capabilities, configuration, and characteristics of the device.
device_hw_info.caption: Device Hardware Info

args.description: The arguments sent along with the HTTP request.
args.caption: HTTP Arguments

version.description: The Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) version.
version.caption: HTTP Version

length.description: The HTTP request length, in number of bytes.
length.caption: Request Length

uid.description: The unique identifier of the http request.
uid.caption: Unique ID

url.description: The URL object that pertains to the request.
url.caption: URL

user_agent.description: The request header that identifies the operating system and web browser.
user_agent.caption: HTTP User-Agent

http_headers.description: Additional HTTP headers of an HTTP request or response.
http_headers.caption: HTTP Headers

OPTIONS.description: The OPTIONS method describes the communication options for the target resource.
OPTIONS.caption: Options

GET.description: The GET method requests a representation of the specified resource. Requests using GET should only retrieve data.
GET.caption: Get

HEAD.description: The HEAD method asks for a response identical to a GET request, but without the response body.
HEAD.caption: Head

POST.description: The POST method submits an entity to the specified resource, often causing a change in state or side effects on the server.
POST.caption: Post

PUT.description: The PUT method replaces all current representations of the target resource with the request payload.
PUT.caption: Put

DELETE.description: The DELETE method deletes the specified resource.
DELETE.caption: Delete

TRACE.description: The TRACE method performs a message loop-back test along the path to the target resource.
TRACE.caption: Trace

CONNECT.description: The CONNECT method establishes a tunnel to the server identified by the target resource.
CONNECT.caption: Connect

http_method.description: The HTTP request method indicates the desired action to be performed for a given resource.
http_method.caption: HTTP Method

referrer.description: The request header that identifies the address of the previous web page, which is linked to the current web page or resource being requested.
referrer.caption: HTTP Referrer

x_forwarded_for.description: The X-Forwarded-For header identifying the originating IP address(es) of a client connecting to a web server through an HTTP proxy or a load balancer.
x_forwarded_for.caption: X-Forwarded-For

http_request.name: http_request
http_request.description: The HTTP Request object represents the attributes of a request made to a web server. It encapsulates the details and metadata associated with an HTTP request, including the request method, headers, URL, query parameters, body content, and other relevant information.
http_request.caption: HTTP Request

version.description: The version of the OCSF schema, using Semantic Versioning Specification (SemVer). For example: 1.0.0. Event consumers use the version to determine the available event attributes.
version.caption: Version

extension.description: The schema extension used to create the event.
extension.caption: Schema Extension

product.description: The product that reported the event.
product.caption: Product

uid.description: The logging system-assigned unique identifier of an event instance.
uid.caption: Event UID

extensions.description: The schema extensions used to create the event.
extensions.caption: Schema Extensions

labels.description:
The list of category labels attached to the event or specific attributes. Labels are user defined tags or aliases added at normalization time.

For example: ["network", "connection.ip:destination", "device.ip:source"]
labels.caption: Labels

log_level.description: The audit level at which an event was generated.
log_level.caption: Log Level

sequence.description: Sequence number of the event. The sequence number is a value available in some events, to make the exact ordering of events unambiguous, regardless of the event time precision.
sequence.caption: Sequence Number

profiles.description: The list of profiles used to create the event.
profiles.caption: Profiles

correlation_uid.description: The unique identifier used to correlate events.
correlation_uid.caption: Correlation UID

data_classification.description: The Data Classification object includes information about data classification levels and data category types.
data_classification.caption: Data Classification

event_code.description: The Event ID or Code that the product uses to describe the event.
event_code.caption: Event Code

log_name.description: The event log name. For example, syslog file name or Windows logging subsystem: Security.
log_name.caption: Log Name

log_provider.description: The logging provider or logging service that logged the event. For example, Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing.
log_provider.caption: Log Provider

log_version.description: The event log schema version that specifies the format of the original event. For example syslog version or Cisco Log Schema Version.
log_version.caption: Log Version

logged_time.description:
The time when the logging system collected and logged the event.

This attribute is distinct from the event time in that event time typically contain the time extracted from the original event. Most of the time, these two times will be different.
logged_time.caption: Logged Time

loggers.description: An array of Logger objects that describe the devices and logging products between the event source and its eventual destination. Note, this attribute can be used when there is a complex end-to-end path of event flow.
loggers.caption: Loggers

modified_time.description: The time when the event was last modified or enriched.
modified_time.caption: Modified Time

original_time.description: The original event time as reported by the event source. For example, the time in the original format from system event log such as Syslog on Unix/Linux and the System event file on Windows. Omit if event is generated instead of collected via logs.
original_time.caption: Original Time

processed_time.description: The event processed time, such as an ETL operation.
processed_time.caption: Processed Time

logged_time_dt.description:
The time when the logging system collected and logged the event.

This attribute is distinct from the event time in that event time typically contain the time extracted from the original event. Most of the time, these two times will be different.
logged_time_dt.caption: Logged Time

modified_time_dt.description: The time when the event was last modified or enriched.
modified_time_dt.caption: Modified Time

processed_time_dt.description: The event processed time, such as an ETL operation.
processed_time_dt.caption: Processed Time

metadata.name: metadata
metadata.description: The Metadata object describes the metadata associated with the event. Defined by D3FEND d3f:Metadata.
metadata.caption: Metadata

name.description: The operating system name.
name.caption: Name

type.description: The type of the operating system.
type.caption: Type

version.description: The version of the OS running on the device that originated the event. For example: "Windows 10", "OS X 10.7", or "iOS 9".
version.caption: Version

country.description: The operating system country code, as defined by the ISO 3166-1 standard (Alpha-2 code). For the complete list of country codes, see ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 codes.
country.caption: Country

lang.description: The two letter lower case language codes, as defined by ISO 639-1. For example: en (English), de (German), or fr (French).
lang.caption: Language

99.description: The type is not mapped. See the type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
99.caption: Other

type_id.description: The type identifier of the operating system.
type_id.caption: Type ID

cpe_name.description: The Common Platform Enumeration (CPE) name as described by (NIST) For example: cpe:/a:apple:safari:16.2.
cpe_name.caption: The product CPE identifier

cpu_bits.description: The cpu architecture, the number of bits used for addressing in memory. For example: 32 or 64.
cpu_bits.caption: CPU Bits

edition.description: The operating system edition. For example: Professional.
edition.caption: OS Edition

sp_name.description: The name of the latest Service Pack.
sp_name.caption: OS Service Pack

sp_ver.description: The version number of the latest Service Pack.
sp_ver.caption: OS Service Pack Version

os.name: os
os.description: The Operating System (OS) object describes characteristics of an OS, such as Linux or Windows. Defined by D3FEND d3f:OperatingSystem.
os.caption: Operating System (OS)

name.description: The tactic name that is associated with the attack technique, as defined by ATT&CK MatrixTM. For example: Reconnaissance.
name.caption: Name

uid.description: The tactic ID that is associated with the attack technique, as defined by ATT&CK MatrixTM. For example: TA0043.
uid.caption: Unique ID

src_url.description: The versioned permalink of the attack tactic, as defined by ATT&CK MatrixTM. For example: https://attack.mitre.org/versions/v14/tactics/TA0043/.
src_url.caption: Source URL

tactic.name: tactic
tactic.description: The Tactic object describes the tactic ID and/or name that is associated to an attack, as defined by ATT&CK MatrixTM.
tactic.caption: Tactic

code.description: The numeric response status code detailing the connection from the load balancer to the destination target.
code.caption: Response Code

message.description: The load balancer message.
message.caption: Message

name.description: The name of the load balancer.
name.caption: Name

uid.description: The unique identifier for the load balancer.
uid.caption: Unique ID

metrics.description: General purpose metrics associated with the load balancer.
metrics.caption: Metrics

classification.description: The request classification as defined by the load balancer.
classification.caption: Classification

dst_endpoint.description: The destination to which the load balancer is distributing traffic.
dst_endpoint.caption: Destination Endpoint

endpoint_connections.description: An object detailing the load balancer connection attempts and responses.
endpoint_connections.caption: Endpoint Connections

status_detail.description: The status detail contains additional status information about the load balancer distribution event.
status_detail.caption: Status Detail

load_balancer.name: load_balancer
load_balancer.description: The load balancer object describes the load balancer entity and contains additional information regarding the distribution of traffic across a network.
load_balancer.caption: Load Balancer

data.description: The data returned from the query execution.
data.caption: Data

name.description: The query name for a saved or scheduled query.
name.caption: Name

bytes.description: The size of the data returned from the query.
bytes.caption: Total Bytes

uid.description: The unique identifier of the query.
uid.caption: Unique ID

query_string.description: A string representing the query code being run. For example: SELECT * FROM my_table
query_string.caption: Query String

query_time.description: The time when the query was run.
query_time.caption: Query Time

query_time_dt.description: The time when the query was run.
query_time_dt.caption: Query Time

query_info.name: query_info
query_info.description: The query info object holds information related to data access within a datastore. To access, manipulate, delete, or retrieve data from a datastore, a query must be written using a specific syntax.
query_info.caption: Query Information

category.description: The name of the data classification category that data matched into, e.g. Financial, Personal, Governmental, etc.
category.caption: Category

3.description: Any financially-related sensitive information or Cardholder Data (CHD). E.g., banking account numbers, credit card numbers, International Banking Account Numbers (IBAN), SWIFT codes, etc.
3.caption: Financial

6.description: Any sensitive security-related data such as passwords, passkeys, IP addresses, API keys, credentials and similar secrets. E.g., AWS Access Secret Key, SaaS API Keys, user passwords, database credentials, etc.
6.caption: Security

99.description: Any other type of data classification or a multi-variate classification made up of several other classification categories.
99.caption: Other

0.description: The type is not mapped. See the data_type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
0.caption: Unknown

1.description: Any Personally Identifiable Information (PII), Electronic Personal Health Information (ePHI), or similarly personal information. E.g., full name, home address, date of birth, etc.
1.caption: Personal

2.description: Any sensitive government identification number related to a person or other classified material. E.g., Passport numbers, driver license numbers, business identification, taxation identifiers, etc.
2.caption: Governmental

4.description: Any business-specific sensitive data such as intellectual property, trademarks, copyrights, human resource data, Board of Directors meeting minutes, and similar.
4.caption: Business

5.description: Any mission-specific sensitive data for military, law enforcement, or other government agencies such as specifically classified data, weapon systems information, or other planning data.
5.caption: Military and Law Enforcement

category_id.description: The normalized identifier of the data classification category.
category_id.caption: Category ID

confidentiality.description: The file content confidentiality, normalized to the confidentiality_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.
confidentiality.caption: Confidentiality

99.description: The confidentiality is not mapped. See the confidentiality attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
99.caption: Other

confidentiality_id.description: The normalized identifier of the file content confidentiality indicator.
confidentiality_id.caption: Confidentiality ID

policy.description: Details about the data policy that governs data handling and security measures related to classification.
policy.caption: Policy

data_classification.name: data_classification
data_classification.description: The Data Classification object includes information about data classification levels and data category types.
data_classification.caption: Data Classification

name.description: The group name.
name.caption: Name

type.description: The type of the group or account.
type.caption: Account Type

domain.description: The domain where the group is defined. For example: the LDAP or Active Directory domain.
domain.caption: Domain

desc.description: The group description.
desc.caption: Description

uid.description: The unique identifier of the group. For example, for Windows events this is the security identifier (SID) of the group.
uid.caption: Unique ID

group.name: group
group.description: The Group object represents a collection or association of entities, such as users, policies, or devices. It serves as a logical grouping mechanism to organize and manage entities with similar characteristics or permissions within a system or organization.
group.caption: Group

name.description: The schema extension name. For example: dev.
name.caption: Name

version.description: The schema extension version. For example: 1.0.0-alpha.2.
version.caption: Version

uid.description: The schema extension unique identifier. For example: 999.
uid.caption: Unique ID

extension.name: extension
extension.description: The OCSF Schema Extension object provides detailed information about the schema extension used to construct the event. The schema extensions are registered in the extensions.md file.
extension.caption: Schema Extension

version.description: The version of the API service.
version.caption: Version

request.description: Details pertaining to the API request.
request.caption: API Request Details

service.description: The information pertaining to the API service.
service.caption: Service

group.description: The information pertaining to the API group.
group.caption: Group

response.description: Details pertaining to the API response.
response.caption: API Response Details

api.name: api
api.description: The API, or Application Programming Interface, object represents  information pertaining to an API request and response.
api.caption: API

type.description:
The vulnerability type as selected from a large dropdown menu during CVE refinement.

Most frequently used vulnerability types are: DoS, Code Execution, Overflow, Memory Corruption, Sql Injection, XSS, Directory Traversal, Http Response Splitting, Bypass something, Gain Information, Gain Privileges, CSRF, File Inclusion. For more information see Vulnerabilities By Type distributions.
type.caption: Vulnerability Type

title.description: A title or a brief phrase summarizing the CVE record.
title.caption: Title

product.description: The product where the vulnerability was discovered.
product.caption: Product

desc.description: A brief description of the CVE Record.
desc.caption: Description

uid.description: The Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures unique number assigned to a specific computer vulnerability. A CVE Identifier begins with 4 digits representing the year followed by a sequence of digits that acts as a unique identifier. For example: CVE-2021-12345.
uid.caption: CVE ID

references.description: A list of reference URLs with additional information about the CVE Record.
references.caption: References

created_time.description: The Record Creation Date identifies when the CVE ID was issued to a CVE Numbering Authority (CNA) or the CVE Record was published on the CVE List. Note that the Record Creation Date does not necessarily indicate when this vulnerability was discovered, shared with the affected vendor, publicly disclosed, or updated in CVE.
created_time.caption: Created Time

cvss.description: The CVSS object details Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) scores from the advisory that are related to the vulnerability.
cvss.caption: CVSS Score

cwe.description: The CWE object represents a weakness in a software system that can be exploited by a threat actor to perform an attack. The CWE object is based on the Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) catalog.
cwe.caption: CWE

cwe_uid.description: The Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) unique identifier. For example: CWE-787.
cwe_uid.caption: CWE UID

@deprecated.message: Use the cwe object attributes instead.

cwe_url.description: Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) definition URL. For example: https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/787.html.
cwe_url.caption: CWE URL

@deprecated.message: Use the cwe object attributes instead.

epss.description: The Exploit Prediction Scoring System (EPSS) object describes the estimated probability a vulnerability will be exploited. EPSS is a community-driven effort to combine descriptive information about vulnerabilities (CVEs) with evidence of actual exploitation in-the-wild. (EPSS).
epss.caption: EPSS

modified_time.description: The Record Modified Date identifies when the CVE record was last updated.
modified_time.caption: Modified Time

created_time_dt.description: The Record Creation Date identifies when the CVE ID was issued to a CVE Numbering Authority (CNA) or the CVE Record was published on the CVE List. Note that the Record Creation Date does not necessarily indicate when this vulnerability was discovered, shared with the affected vendor, publicly disclosed, or updated in CVE.
created_time_dt.caption: Created Time

modified_time_dt.description: The Record Modified Date identifies when the CVE record was last updated.
modified_time_dt.caption: Modified Time

cve.name: cve
cve.description: The Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) object represents publicly disclosed cybersecurity vulnerabilities defined in CVE Program catalog (CVE). There is one CVE Record for each vulnerability in the catalog.
cve.caption: CVE

policy.description: Details about the Identity/Access management policies that are applicable.
policy.caption: Policy

authorization.name: authorization
authorization.description: The Authorization Result object provides details about the authorization outcome and associated policies related to activity.
authorization.caption: Authorization Result

name.description: The administrator-supplied or application-generated name of the scan. For example: "Home office weekly user database scan", "Scan folders for viruses", "Full system virus scan"
name.caption: Name

type.description: The type of scan.
type.caption: Type

uid.description: The application-defined unique identifier assigned to an instance of a scan.
uid.caption: Scan UID

3.description: The scan was triggered by a content update.
3.caption: Updated Content

6.description: The scan was started due to a user logon.
6.caption: User Logon

99.description: The scan type id is not mapped. See the type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
99.caption: Other

1.description: The scan was manually initiated by the user or administrator.
1.caption: Manual

2.description: The scan was started based on scheduler.
2.caption: Scheduled

4.description: The scan was triggered by newly quarantined items.
4.caption: Quarantined Items

5.description: The scan was triggered by the attachment of removable media.
5.caption: Attached Media

7.description: The scan was triggered by an Early Launch Anti-Malware (ELAM) detection.
7.caption: ELAM

type_id.description: The type id of the scan.
type_id.caption: Type ID

scan.name: scan
scan.description: The Scan object describes characteristics of a proactive scan.
scan.caption: Scan

name.description: The HTTP cookie name.
name.caption: Name

path.description: The path of the HTTP cookie.
path.caption: Path

secure.description: The cookie attribute to only send cookies to the server with an encrypted request over the HTTPS protocol.
secure.caption: Secure

http_only.description: A cookie attribute to make it inaccessible via JavaScript
http_only.caption: HTTP Only

expiration_time.description: The expiration time of the HTTP cookie.
expiration_time.caption: Expiration Time

is_http_only.description: This attribute prevents the cookie from being accessed via JavaScript.
is_http_only.caption: HTTP Only

is_secure.description: The cookie attribute indicates that cookies are sent to the server only when the request is encrypted using the HTTPS protocol.
is_secure.caption: Secure

samesite.description: The cookie attribute that lets servers specify whether/when cookies are sent with cross-site requests. Values are: Strict, Lax or None
samesite.caption: SameSite

expiration_time_dt.description: The expiration time of the HTTP cookie.
expiration_time_dt.caption: Expiration Time

http_cookie.name: http_cookie
http_cookie.description: The HTTP Cookie object, also known as a web cookie or browser cookie, contains details and values pertaining to a small piece of data that a server sends to a user's web browser. This data is then stored by the browser and sent back to the server with subsequent requests, allowing the server to remember and track certain information about the user's browsing session or preferences.
http_cookie.caption: HTTP Cookie

name.description: The malware name, as reported by the detection engine.
name.caption: Name

path.description: The filesystem path of the malware that was observed.
path.caption: Path

uid.description: The malware unique identifier, as reported by the detection engine. For example a virus id or an IPS signature id.
uid.caption: Unique ID

classification_ids.description: The list of normalized identifiers of the malware classifications. Reference: STIX Malware Types
classification_ids.caption: Classification IDs

classifications.description: The list of malware classifications, normalized to the captions of the classification_id values. In the case of 'Other', they are defined by the event source.
classifications.caption: Classifications

cves.description: List of Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE).
cves.caption: CVE List

provider.description: The provider of the malware information.
provider.caption: Provider

malware.name: malware
malware.description: The Malware object describes the classification of known malicious software, which is intentionally designed to cause damage to a computer, server, client, or computer network.
malware.caption: Malware

name.description: The container name.
name.caption: Name

runtime.description: The backend running the container, such as containerd or cri-o.
runtime.caption: Runtime

size.description: The size of the container image.
size.caption: Size

tag.description: The tag used by the container. It can indicate version, format, OS.
tag.caption: Image Tag

uid.description: The full container unique identifier for this instantiation of the container. For example: ac2ea168264a08f9aaca0dfc82ff3551418dfd22d02b713142a6843caa2f61bf.
uid.caption: Unique ID

image.description: The container image used as a template to run the container.
image.caption: Image

hash.description: Commit hash of image created for docker or the SHA256 hash of the container. For example: 13550340a8681c84c861aac2e5b440161c2b33a3e4f302ac680ca5b686de48de.
hash.caption: Hash

network_driver.description: The network driver used by the container. For example, bridge, overlay, host, none, etc.
network_driver.caption: Network Driver

orchestrator.description: The orchestrator managing the container, such as ECS, EKS, K8s, or OpenShift.
orchestrator.caption: Orchestrator

pod_uuid.description: The unique identifier of the pod (or equivalent) that the container is executing on.
pod_uuid.caption: Pod UUID

container.name: container
container.description: The Container object describes an instance of a specific container. A container is a prepackaged, portable system image that runs isolated on an existing system using a container runtime like containerd.
container.caption: Container

desc.description: The description of the remediation strategy.
desc.caption: Description

references.description: A list of supporting URL/s, references that help describe the remediation strategy.
references.caption: References

kb_articles.description: The KB article/s related to the entity. A KB Article contains metadata that describes the patch or an update.
kb_articles.caption: Knowledgebase Articles

kb_article_list.description: A list of KB articles or patches related to an endpoint. A KB Article contains metadata that describes the patch or an update.
kb_article_list.caption: Knowledgebase Articles

remediation.name: remediation
remediation.description: The Remediation object describes the recommended remediation steps to address identified issue(s).
remediation.caption: Remediation

algorithm.description: The hash algorithm used to create the digital fingerprint, normalized to the caption of 'algorithm_id'. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.
algorithm.caption: Algorithm

3.description: Secure Hash Algorithm 2 producing a 256-bit (32-byte) hash value.
3.caption: SHA-256

6.description: The TLSH fuzzy hashing algorithm.
6.caption: TLSH

99.description: The algorithm is not mapped. See the algorithm attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
99.caption: Other

1.description: MD5 message-digest algorithm producing a 128-bit (16-byte) hash value.
1.caption: MD5

2.description: Secure Hash Algorithm 1 producing a 160-bit (20-byte) hash value.
2.caption: SHA-1

4.description: Secure Hash Algorithm 2 producing a 512-bit (64-byte) hash value.
4.caption: SHA-512

5.description: The ssdeep generated fuzzy checksum. Also known as Context Triggered Piecewise Hash (CTPH).
5.caption: CTPH

7.description: Microsoft simple non-cryptographic hash algorithm that works by XORing the bytes in a circular-shifting fashion.
7.caption: quickXorHash

algorithm_id.description: The identifier of the normalized hash algorithm, which was used to create the digital fingerprint.
algorithm_id.caption: Algorithm ID

fingerprint.name: fingerprint
fingerprint.description: The Fingerprint object provides detailed information about a digital fingerprint, which is a compact representation of data used to identify a longer piece of information, such as a public key or file content. It contains the algorithm and value of the fingerprint, enabling efficient and reliable identification of the associated data.
fingerprint.caption: Fingerprint

object.name: object
object.description: An unordered collection of attributes. It defines a set of attributes available in all objects. It can be also used as a generic object to log objects that are not otherwise defined by the schema.
object.caption: Object

name.description: The username. For example, janedoe1.
name.caption: Name

type.description: The type of the user. For example, System, AWS IAM User, etc.
type.caption: Type

domain.description: The domain where the user is defined. For example: the LDAP or Active Directory domain.
domain.caption: Domain

uid.description: The unique user identifier. For example, the Windows user SID, ActiveDirectory DN or AWS user ARN.
uid.caption: Unique ID

org.description: Organization and org unit related to the user.
org.caption: Organization

groups.description: The administrative groups to which the user belongs.
groups.caption: Groups

full_name.description: The full name of the person, as per the LDAP Common Name attribute (cn).
full_name.caption: Full Name

3.description: System account. For example, Windows computer accounts with a trailing dollar sign ($).
3.caption: System

99.description: The type is not mapped. See the type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
99.caption: Other

1.description: Regular user account.
1.caption: User

2.description: Admin/root user account.
2.caption: Admin

account.description: The user's account or the account associated with the user.
account.caption: Account

credential_uid.description: The unique identifier of the user's credential. For example, AWS Access Key ID.
credential_uid.caption: User Credential ID

ldap_person.description: The additional LDAP attributes that describe a person.
ldap_person.caption: LDAP Person

risk_level.description: The risk level, normalized to the caption of the risk_level_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.
risk_level.caption: Risk Level

risk_score.description: The risk score as reported by the event source.
risk_score.caption: Risk Score

uid_alt.description: The alternate user identifier. For example, the Active Directory user GUID or AWS user Principal ID.
uid_alt.caption: Alternate ID

user.name: user
user.description: The User object describes the characteristics of a user/person or a security principal. Defined by D3FEND d3f:UserAccount.
user.caption: User

process.description: The process that initiated the activity.
process.caption: Process

session.description: The user session from which the activity was initiated.
session.caption: Session

user.description: The user that initiated the activity or the user context from which the activity was initiated.
user.caption: User

app_name.description: The client application or service that initiated the activity. This can be in conjunction with the user if present. Note that app_name is distinct from the process if present.
app_name.caption: Application Name

app_uid.description: The unique identifier of the client application or service that initiated the activity. This can be in conjunction with the user if present. Note that app_name is distinct from the process.pid or process.uid if present.
app_uid.caption: Application ID

authorizations.description: Provides details about an authorization, such as authorization outcome, and any associated policies related to the activity/event.
authorizations.caption: Authorization Information

idp.description: This object describes details about the Identity Provider used.
idp.caption: Identity Provider

invoked_by.description: The name of the service that invoked the activity as described in the event.
invoked_by.caption: Invoked by

actor.name: actor
actor.description: The Actor object contains details about the user, role, application, service, or process that initiated or performed a specific activity.
actor.caption: Actor

name.description: The name of the feature.
name.caption: Name

version.description: The version of the feature.
version.caption: Version

uid.description: The unique identifier of the feature.
uid.caption: Unique ID

feature.name: feature
feature.description: The Feature object provides information about the software product feature that generated a specific event. It encompasses details related to the capabilities, components, user interface (UI) design, and performance upgrades associated with the feature.
feature.caption: Feature

name.description: Organization name for the Autonomous System.
name.caption: Name

number.description: Unique number that the AS is identified by.
number.caption: Number

autonomous_system.name: autonomous_system
autonomous_system.description: An autonomous system (AS) is a collection of connected Internet Protocol (IP) routing prefixes under the control of one or more network operators on behalf of a single administrative entity or domain that presents a common, clearly defined routing policy to the internet.
autonomous_system.caption: Autonomous System

name.description: The name of the header
name.caption: Name

http_header.name: http_header
http_header.description: TThe HTTP Header object represents the headers sent in an HTTP request or response. HTTP headers are key-value pairs that convey additional information about the HTTP message, including details about the content, caching, authentication, encoding, and other aspects of the communication.
http_header.caption: HTTP Header

name.description: The name of the agent or sensor. For example: AWS SSM Agent.
name.caption: Agent Name

type.description: The normalized caption of the type_id value for the agent or sensor. In the case of 'Other' or 'Unknown', it is defined by the event source.
type.caption: Agent Type

version.description: The semantic version of the agent or sensor, e.g., 7.101.50.0.
version.caption: Agent Version

uid.description: The UID of the agent or sensor, sometimes known as a Sensor ID or aid.
uid.caption: Agent ID

3.description: Any agent or sensor that provides backups, archival, or recovery capabilities. E.g., Azure Backup, AWS Backint Agent.
3.caption: Backup & Recovery

6.description: Any agent or sensor that forwards logs to a 3rd party storage system such as a data lake or SIEM. E.g., Splunk Universal Forwarder, Tenzir, FluentBit, Amazon CloudWatch Agent, Amazon Kinesis Agent.
6.caption: Log Forwarding

99.description: The type is not mapped. See the type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
99.caption: Other

1.description: Any EDR sensor or agent. Or any tool that provides similar threat detection, anti-malware, anti-ransomware, or similar capabilities. E.g., Crowdstrike Falcon, Microsoft Defender for Endpoint, Wazuh.
1.caption: Endpoint Detection and Response

2.description: Any DLP sensor or agent. Or any tool that provides similar data classification, data loss detection, and/or data loss prevention capabilities. E.g., Forcepoint DLP, Microsoft Purview, Symantec DLP.
2.caption: Data Loss Prevention

4.description: Any agent or sensor that provides Application Performance Monitoring (APM), active tracing, profiling, or other observability use cases and optionally forwards the logs. E.g., New Relic Agent, Datadog Agent, Azure Monitor Agent.
4.caption: Performance Monitoring & Observability

5.description: Any agent or sensor that provides vulnerability management or scanning capabilities. E.g., Qualys VMDR, Microsoft Defender for Endpoint, Crowdstrike Spotlight, Amazon Inspector Agent.
5.caption: Vulnerability Management

7.description: Any agent or sensor responsible for providing Mobile Device Management (MDM) or Mobile Enterprise Management (MEM) capabilities. E.g., JumpCloud Agent, Esper Agent, Jamf Pro binary.
7.caption: Mobile Device Management

8.description: Any agent or sensor that provides configuration management of a device, such as scanning for software, license management, or applying configurations. E.g., AWS Systems Manager Agent, Flexera, ServiceNow MID Server.
8.caption: Configuration Management

9.description: Any agent or sensor that provides remote access capabilities to a device. E.g., BeyondTrust, Amazon Systems Manager Agent, Verkada Agent.
9.caption: Remote Access

type_id.description: The normalized representation of an agent or sensor. E.g., EDR, vulnerability management, APM, backup & recovery, etc.
type_id.caption: Type ID

policies.description: Describes the various policies that may be applied or enforced by an agent or sensor. E.g., Conditional Access, prevention, auto-update, tamper protection, destination configuration, etc.
policies.caption: Agent Policies

uid_alt.description: An alternative or contextual identifier for the agent or sensor, such as a configuration, organization, or license UID.
uid_alt.caption: Alternate Agent ID

vendor_name.description: The company or author who created the agent or sensor. For example: Crowdstrike.
vendor_name.caption: Vendor Name

agent.name: agent
agent.description: An Agent (also known as a Sensor) is typically installed on an Operating System (OS) and serves as a specialized software component that can be designed to monitor, detect, collect, archive, or take action. These activities and possible actions are defined by the upstream system controlling the Agent and its intended purpose. For instance, an Agent can include Endpoint Detection & Response (EDR) agents, backup/disaster recovery sensors, Application Performance Monitoring or profiling sensors, and similar software.
agent.caption: Agent

count.description: The number of identical sessions spawned from the same source IP, destination IP, application, and content/threat type seen over a period of time.
count.caption: Count

terminal.description: The Pseudo Terminal associated with the session. Ex: the tty or pts value.
terminal.caption: Terminal

uid.description: The unique identifier of the session.
uid.caption: Unique ID

uuid.description: The universally unique identifier of the session.
uuid.caption: UUID

issuer.description: The identifier of the session issuer.
issuer.caption: Issuer Details

created_time.description: The time when the session was created.
created_time.caption: Created Time

credential_uid.description: The unique identifier of the user's credential. For example, AWS Access Key ID.
credential_uid.caption: User Credential ID

expiration_reason.description: The reason which triggered the session expiration.
expiration_reason.caption: Expiration Reason

is_mfa.description: Indicates whether Multi Factor Authentication was used during authentication.
is_mfa.caption: Multi Factor Authentication

is_remote.description: The indication of whether the session is remote.
is_remote.caption: Remote

is_vpn.description: The indication of whether the session is a VPN session.
is_vpn.caption: VPN Session

uid_alt.description: The alternate unique identifier of the session. e.g. AWS ARN - arn:aws:sts::123344444444:assumed-role/Admin/example-session.
uid_alt.caption: Alternate ID

created_time_dt.description: The time when the session was created.
created_time_dt.caption: Created Time

session.name: session
session.description: The Session object describes details about an authenticated session. e.g. Session Creation Time, Session Issuer. Defined by D3FEND d3f:Session.
session.caption: Session

org.description: Organization and org unit relevant to the event or object.
org.caption: Organization

account.description: The account object describes details about the account that was the source or target of the activity.
account.caption: Account

project_uid.description: The unique identifier of a Cloud project.
project_uid.caption: Project ID

provider.description: The unique name of the Cloud services provider, such as AWS, MS Azure, GCP, etc.
provider.caption: Provider

region.description: The name of the cloud region, as defined by the cloud provider.
region.caption: Region

zone.description: The availability zone in the cloud region, as defined by the cloud provider.
zone.caption: Network Zone

cloud.name: cloud
cloud.description: The Cloud object contains information about a cloud account such as AWS Account ID, regions, etc.
cloud.caption: Cloud

name.description: The name of the analytic that generated the finding.
name.caption: Name

type.description: The analytic type.
type.caption: Type

version.description: The analytic version. For example: 1.1.
version.caption: Version

desc.description: The description of the analytic that generated the finding.
desc.caption: Description

uid.description: The unique identifier of the analytic that generated the finding.
uid.caption: Unique ID

3.description: Statistical analytics pertains to analyzing data patterns and anomalies using statistical models to predict, detect, and respond to potential threats, enhancing overall security posture through informed decision-making.
3.caption: Statistical

6.description: Tagging refers to the practice of assigning labels or identifiers to data, users, assets, or activities to monitor, control access, and facilitate incident response across various security domains such as DLP and EDR.
6.caption: Tagging

99.description: The type is not mapped. See the type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
99.caption: Other

1.description: A Rule in security analytics refers to predefined criteria or conditions set to monitor, alert, or enforce policies, playing a crucial role in access control, threat detection, and regulatory compliance across security systems.
1.caption: Rule

2.description: Behavioral analytics focus on monitoring and analyzing user or system actions to identify deviations from established patterns, aiding in the detection of insider threats, fraud, and advanced persistent threats (APTs).
2.caption: Behavioral

10.description: Partial Data Match involves identifying instances where segments of sensitive information or patterns match, facilitating nuanced DLP and threat detection without requiring complete data conformity.
10.caption: Partial Data Match

5.description: Fingerprinting is the technique of collecting detailed system data, including software versions and configurations, to enhance threat detection, data loss prevention (DLP), and endpoint detection and response (EDR) capabilities.
5.caption: Fingerprinting

7.description: Keyword Match involves scanning content for specific terms to identify sensitive information, potential threats, or policy violations, aiding in DLP and compliance monitoring.
7.caption: Keyword Match

8.description: Regular Expressions are used to define complex search patterns for identifying, validating, and extracting specific data sets or threats within digital content, enhancing DLP, EDR, and threat detection mechanisms.
8.caption: Regular Expressions

9.description: Exact Data Match is a precise comparison technique used to detect the unauthorized use or exposure of specific, sensitive information, crucial for enforcing DLP policies and protecting against data breaches.
9.caption: Exact Data Match

11.description: Indexed Data Match refers to comparing content against a pre-compiled index of sensitive information to efficiently detect and prevent unauthorized access or breaches, streamlining DLP and compliance efforts.
11.caption: Indexed Data Match

related_analytics.description: Other analytics related to this analytic.
related_analytics.caption: Related Analytics

This attribute is distinct from the event time in that event time typically contain the time extracted from the original event. Most of the time, these two times will be different.

logged_time_dt.description:
The time when the logging system collected and logged the event.

14.description:
Observable by Dictionary Attribute.
The ISO 3166-1 Alpha-2 country code. For the complete list of country codes see ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 codes.

Note: The two letter country code should be capitalized. For example: US or CA.
14.caption: Country

15.description:
Observable by Dictionary Attribute.
The process identifier, as reported by the operating system. Process ID (PID) is a number used by the operating system to uniquely identify an active process.
15.caption: Process ID

16.description:
Observable by Dictionary Attribute.
The request header that identifies the operating system and web browser.
16.caption: HTTP User-Agent

17.description:
Observable by Object-Specific Attribute.
Object-specific attribute "uid" for the CWE Object.
17.caption: CWE Object: uid

18.description:
Observable by Object-Specific Attribute.
Object-specific attribute "uid" for the CVE Object.
18.caption: CVE Object: uid

20.description:
Observable by Object.
The Endpoint object describes a physical or virtual device that connects to and exchanges information with a computer network. Some examples of endpoints are mobile devices, desktop computers, virtual machines, embedded devices, and servers. Internet-of-Things devices—like cameras, lighting, refrigerators, security systems, smart speakers, and thermostats—are also endpoints.
20.caption: Endpoint

21.description:
Observable by Object.
The User object describes the characteristics of a user/person or a security principal. Defined by D3FEND d3f:UserAccount.
21.caption: User

22.description:
Observable by Object.
The Email object describes the email metadata such as sender, recipients, and direction. Defined by D3FEND d3f:Email.
22.caption: Email

23.description:
Observable by Object.
The Uniform Resource Locator(URL) object describes the characteristics of a URL. Defined in RFC 1738 and by D3FEND d3f:URL.
23.caption: Uniform Resource Locator

24.description:
Observable by Object.
The File object represents the metadata associated with a file stored in a computer system. It encompasses information about the file itself, including its attributes, properties, and organizational details. Defined by D3FEND d3f:File.
24.caption: File

25.description:
Observable by Object.
The Process object describes a running instance of a launched program. Defined by D3FEND d3f:Process.
25.caption: Process

26.description:
Observable by Object.
The Geo Location object describes a geographical location, usually associated with an IP address. Defined by D3FEND d3f:PhysicalLocation.
26.caption: Geo Location

27.description:
Observable by Object.
The Container object describes an instance of a specific container. A container is a prepackaged, portable system image that runs isolated on an existing system using a container runtime like containerd.
27.caption: Container

29.description:
Observable by Object.
The registry value object describes a Windows registry value.
29.caption: Registry Value

30.description:
Observable by Object.
The Fingerprint object provides detailed information about a digital fingerprint, which is a compact representation of data used to identify a longer piece of information, such as a public key or file content. It contains the algorithm and value of the fingerprint, enabling efficient and reliable identification of the associated data.
30.caption: Fingerprint

12.description:
Observable by Dictionary Type.
The subnet represented in a CIDR notation, using the format network_address/prefix_length. The network_address can be in either IPv4 or IPv6 format. The prefix length indicates the number of bits used for the network portion, and the remaining bits are available for host addresses within that subnet.
For example:
  • 192.168.1.0/24
  • 2001:0db8:85a3:0000::/64
12.caption: Subnet

13.description:
Observable by Dictionary Attribute.
The full command line used to launch an application, service, process, or job. For example: ssh user@10.0.0.10. If the command line is unavailable or missing, the empty string '' is to be used.
13.caption: Command Line

28.description:
Observable by Object.
The registry key object describes a Windows registry key. Defined by D3FEND d3f:WindowsRegistryKey.
28.caption: Registry Key

reputation.description: Contains the original and normalized reputation scores.
reputation.caption: Reputation Scores

zone.description: The network zone or LAN segment.

network_proxy.name: network_proxy
network_proxy.description: The network proxy endpoint object describes a proxy server, which acts as an intermediary between a client requesting a resource and the server providing that resource. Defined by D3FEND d3f:ProxyServer.

database.description: The database object is used for databases which are typically datastore services that contain an organized collection of structured and unstructured data or a types of data.
database.caption: Database

bytes_in.description: The number of bytes sent from the destination to the source.
bytes_in.caption: Bytes In

bytes_out.description: The number of bytes sent from the source to the destination.
bytes_out.caption: Bytes Out

chunks.description: The total number of chunks (in and out).
chunks.caption: Chunks

bytes.description: The total number of bytes (in and out).
bytes.caption: Total Bytes

chunks_in.description: The number of chunks sent from the destination to the source.

chunks_out.description: The number of chunks sent from the source to the destination.

network_traffic.name: network_traffic
network_traffic.description: The Network Traffic object describes characteristics of network traffic. Network traffic refers to data moving across a network at a given point of time. Defined by D3FEND d3f:NetworkTraffic.
network_traffic.caption: Network Traffic

name.description: The software package name.
name.caption: Name

version.description: The software package version.
version.caption: Version

release.description: Release is the number of times a version of the software has been packaged.
release.caption: Software Release Details

epoch.description: The software package epoch. Epoch is a way to define weighted dependencies based on version numbers.
epoch.caption: Epoch

license.description: The software license applied to this package.
license.caption: Software License

architecture.description: Architecture is a shorthand name describing the type of computer hardware the packaged software is meant to run on.
architecture.caption: Architecture

purl.description: A purl is a URL string used to identify and locate a software package in a mostly universal and uniform way across programming languages, package managers, packaging conventions, tools, APIs and databases.
purl.caption: Package URL

package.name: package
package.description: The Software Package object describes details about a software package. Defined by D3FEND d3f:SoftwarePackage.
package.caption: Software Package

version.description: The CVSS version. For example: 3.1.
version.caption: Version

depth.description: The CVSS depth represents a depth of the equation used to calculate CVSS score.
depth.caption: CVSS Depth

severity.description:
The Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) Qualitative Severity Rating. A textual representation of the numeric score.

CVSS v2.0
  • Low (0.0 – 3.9)
  • Medium (4.0 – 6.9)
  • High (7.0 – 10.0)

CVSS v3.0
  • None (0.0)
  • Low (0.1 - 3.9)
  • Medium (4.0 - 6.9)
  • High (7.0 - 8.9)
  • Critical (9.0 - 10.0)
severity.caption: Severity

metrics.description: The Common Vulnerability Scoring System metrics. This attribute contains information on the CVE's impact. If the CVE has been analyzed, this attribute will contain any CVSSv2 or CVSSv3 information associated with the vulnerability. For example: { {"Access Vector", "Network"}, {"Access Complexity", "Low"}, ...}.
metrics.caption: Metrics

base_score.description: The CVSS base score. For example: 9.1.
base_score.caption: Base Score

overall_score.description: The CVSS overall score, impacted by base, temporal, and environmental metrics. For example: 9.1.
overall_score.caption: Overall Score

vector_string.description: The CVSS vector string is a text representation of a set of CVSS metrics. It is commonly used to record or transfer CVSS metric information in a concise form. For example: 3.1/AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:H.
vector_string.caption: Vector String

cvss.name: cvss
cvss.description: The Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) object provides a way to capture the principal characteristics of a vulnerability and produce a numerical score reflecting its severity.
cvss.caption: CVSS Score

code.description: A numerical response status code providing details about the connection.
code.caption: Response Code

network_endpoint.description: Provides characteristics of the network endpoint.
network_endpoint.caption: Network Endpoint

endpoint_connection.name: endpoint_connection
endpoint_connection.description: The Endpoint Connection object contains information detailing a connection attempt to an endpoint.
endpoint_connection.caption: Endpoint Connection

version.description: The ATT&CK MatrixTM version.
version.caption: Version

tactics.description: The Tactic object describes the tactic ID and/or tactic name that are associated with the attack technique, as defined by ATT&CK MatrixTM.
tactics.caption: Tactics

technique.description: The Technique object describes the technique ID and/or name associated to an attack, as defined by ATT&CK MatrixTM.
technique.caption: Technique

sub_technique.description: The Sub Technique object describes the sub technique ID and/or name associated to an attack, as defined by ATT&CK MatrixTM.
sub_technique.caption: Sub Technique

tactic.description: The Tactic object describes the tactic ID and/or name that is associated to an attack, as defined by ATT&CK MatrixTM.
tactic.caption: Tactic

attack.name: attack
attack.description: The MITRE ATT&CK® object describes the tactic, technique & sub-technique associated to an attack as defined in ATT&CK MatrixTM.
attack.caption: MITRE ATT&CK®

data.description: Additional evidence data that is not accounted for in the specific evidence attributes. Use only when absolutely necessary.
data.caption: Data

process.description: Describes details about the process associated to the activity that triggered the detection.
process.caption: Process

file.description: Describes details about the file associated to the activity that triggered the detection.
file.caption: File

query.description: Describes details about the DNS query associated to the activity that triggered the detection.
query.caption: DNS Query

connection_info.description: Describes details about the network connection associated to the activity that triggered the detection.
connection_info.caption: Connection Info

api.description: Describes details about the API call associated to the activity that triggered the detection.
api.caption: API Details

actor.description: Describes details about the user/role/process that was the source of the activity that triggered the detection.
actor.caption: Actor

container.description: Describes details about the container associated to the activity that triggered the detection.
container.caption: Container

database.description: Describes details about the database associated to the activity that triggered the detection.
database.caption: Database

databucket.description: Describes details about the databucket associated to the activity that triggered the detection.
databucket.caption: Databucket

dst_endpoint.description: Describes details about the destination of the network activity that triggered the detection.
dst_endpoint.caption: Destination Endpoint

src_endpoint.description: Describes details about the source of the network activity that triggered the detection.
src_endpoint.caption: Source Endpoint

evidences.name: evidences
evidences.description: A collection of evidence artifacts associated to the activity/activities that triggered a security detection.
evidences.caption: Evidence Artifacts

json_t.description: Embedded JSON value. A value can be a string, or a number, or true or false or null, or an object or an array. These structures can be nested. See www.json.org.
json_t.caption: JSON

datetime_t.description: The Internet Date/Time format as defined in RFC-3339. For example 1985-04-12T23:20:50.52Z.
datetime_t.caption: Datetime

file_hash_t.description: Hash. A unique value that corresponds to the content of the file, image, ja3_hash or hassh found in the schema. For example MD5: 3172ac7e2b55cbb81f04a6e65855a628.
file_hash_t.caption: Hash

hostname_t.description: Unique name assigned to a device connected to a computer network. A domain name in general is an Internet address that can be resolved through the Domain Name System (DNS). For example: r2-d2.example.com.
hostname_t.caption: Hostname

ip_t.description: Internet Protocol address (IP address), in either IPv4 or IPv6 format. For example, 192.168.200.24 or 2001:0db8:85a3:0000:0000:8a2e:0370:7334.
ip_t.caption: IP Address

mac_t.description: Media Access Control (MAC) address. For example: 18:36:F3:98:4F:9A.
mac_t.caption: MAC Address

port_t.description: The TCP/UDP port number. For example: 80 or 22.
port_t.caption: Port

resource_uid_t.description: Resource unique identifier. For example, S3 Bucket name or EC2 Instance ID.
resource_uid_t.caption: Resource UID

subnet_t.description:
The subnet represented in a CIDR notation, using the format network_address/prefix_length. The network_address can be in either IPv4 or IPv6 format. The prefix length indicates the number of bits used for the network portion, and the remaining bits are available for host addresses within that subnet.
For example:
  • 192.168.1.0/24
  • 2001:0db8:85a3:0000::/64
subnet_t.caption: Subnet

timestamp_t.description: The timestamp format is the number of milliseconds since the Epoch 01/01/1970 00:00:00 UTC. For example 1618524549901.
timestamp_t.caption: Timestamp

url_t.description: Uniform Resource Locator (URL) string. For example: http://www.example.com/download/trouble.exe.
url_t.caption: URL String

count.description: The number of times that events in the same logical group occurred during the event Start Time to End Time period.
count.caption: Count

message.description: The description of the event/finding, as defined by the source.
message.caption: Message

status.description: The event status, normalized to the caption of the status_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.
status.caption: Status

time.description: The normalized event occurrence time or the finding creation time.
time.caption: Event Time

metadata.description: The metadata associated with the event or a finding.
metadata.caption: Metadata

start_time.description: The start time of a time period, or the time of the least recent event included in the aggregate event.
start_time.caption: Start Time

severity.description: The event/finding severity, normalized to the caption of the severity_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the source.
severity.caption: Severity

duration.caption: Duration

api.description: Describes details about a typical API (Application Programming Interface) call.
api.caption: API Details

timezone_offset.description: The number of minutes that the reported event time is ahead or behind UTC, in the range -1,080 to +1,080.
timezone_offset.caption: Timezone Offset

activity_id.caption: Activity ID

[{"name": "answers.ip", "value": "92.24.47.250", "type": "location", "data": {"city": "Socotra", "continent": "Asia", "coordinates": [-25.4153, 17.0743], "country": "YE", "desc": "Yemen"}}]

6.description: An error occurred but it is too late to take remedial action.

5.description: Action is required immediately and the scope is broad.

The normalized identifier of the event/finding severity.

The normalized severity is a measurement the effort and expense required to manage and resolve an event or incident. Smaller numerical values represent lower impact events, and larger numerical values represent higher impact events.
